org.dsa.iot.commons

Class GuaranteedReceiver<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.dsa.iot.commons.GuaranteedReceiver<T>

  • public abstract class GuaranteedReceiver<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    The GuaranteedReceiver is designed to guarantee retrieving an instance of T. The instance will be instantiated as necessary. A trivial use case is to support automatically reconnecting to servers in an elegant and standard fashion.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      GuaranteedReceiver(long delay)
      Constructs a GuaranteedReceiver with a specified delay.
      GuaranteedReceiver(long delay, boolean loop) 
      GuaranteedReceiver(long delay, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit, boolean loop)
      The instance of T will not be initially initialized until get(org.dsa.iot.dslink.util.handler.Handler<T>, boolean) is called or looping is enabled.

      • GuaranteedReceiver

        public GuaranteedReceiver(long delay)
        Constructs a GuaranteedReceiver with a specified delay.
        Parameters:
        delay - Delay, in seconds, to instantiate the instance if an error occurs.
        See Also:
        GuaranteedReceiver(long, boolean)

      • GuaranteedReceiver

        public GuaranteedReceiver(long delay,
                          boolean loop)
        Parameters:
        delay - Delay, in seconds, to instantiate the instance if an error occurs.
        loop - Whether to enable looping or not.
        See Also:
        GuaranteedReceiver(long, TimeUnit, boolean)

      • GuaranteedReceiver

        public GuaranteedReceiver(long delay,
                          java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit,
                          boolean loop)
        The instance of T will not be initially initialized until get(org.dsa.iot.dslink.util.handler.Handler<T>, boolean) is called or looping is enabled. If looping is enabled then onLoop(T) will be called repeatedly when the delay time elapses based on the specified unit of time.
        Parameters:
        delay - Delay to instantiate the instance, in the specified TimeUnit, to instantiate the instance if an error occurs.
        unit - Unit of time the delay is in.
        loop - Whether to enable looping or not.

    • Method Detail

      • instantiate

        protected abstract T instantiate()
                          throws java.lang.Exception
        Creates the instance of T.
        Returns:
        The created instance of T
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - An error occurred creating the instance.

      • invalidateInstance

        protected abstract boolean invalidateInstance(java.lang.Exception e)
        If the instance of T is invalidated, then it will be set to null and be re-instantiated, otherwise the current instance of T will not be set to null. If the instance is not invalidated then it will be treated as an unhandled exception and will be logged.
        Parameters:
        e - Exception that occurred when instantiating or calling a handler.
        Returns:
        Whether to invalidate the instance or not. It is recommended to return false by default.

      • onLoop

        protected void onLoop(T event)
        Called every time a loop occurs. The looping feature must be enabled. A loop is called based on the desired delay. The loop functionality is designed to test if a resource is still being held to determine a status as needed. A RuntimeException must be thrown in order to invalidate the instance. The implementation of invalidateInstance(Exception) will determine if the instance should be invalidated.
        Parameters:
        event - Instantiated T.
        See Also:
        GuaranteedReceiver(long, TimeUnit, boolean), invalidateInstance(Exception)

      • get

        public final void get(Handler<T> handler,
                      boolean checked)
        Guarantees the instance of T is available for consumption. The handler will persist by default.
        Parameters:
        handler - Called when the instance has been retrieved and is ready for consumption.
        checked - If the receiver is shutdown and checked is true then IllegalStateException is thrown, otherwise the handler gets ignored.

      • get

        public final void get(Handler<T> handler,
                      boolean checked,
                      boolean persist)
        Guarantees the instance of T is available for consumption.
        Parameters:
        handler - Called when the instance has been retrieved and is ready for consumption.
        checked - If the receiver is shutdown and checked is true then IllegalStateException is thrown, otherwise the handler gets ignored.
        persist - Whether to persist the handler in a cache if the instance is not ready yet or an exception has occurred.

      • shutdown

        public T shutdown()
        Shuts down the receiver from preventing any new instances to be created. If the looping feature is enabled then it will be shutdown as well.
        Returns:
        The underlying instance of T, which can be null, to allow freeing any resources the instance holds.
